headline: Southern Fried Chicken Livers
description: These crispy fried chicken livers are seasoned with garlic powder and ready to serve in just 20 minutes for a popular old-time Southern treat!

video.name: How to Make Southern Fried Chicken Livers

name: Southern Fried Chicken Livers

recipeInstructions.text: Place chicken livers in a colander; rinse with cold water and drain well. Blot dry with paper towels.
Whisk egg and milk together in a shallow dish until blended.
Place flour, garlic powder, salt, and pepper into a zip-top bag; shake to combine.
Heat oil in a deep fryer or large saucepan to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
Dip chicken livers in egg mixture to coat, then transfer, one at a time, into flour mixture, shaking the bag to coat completely.
Gently place coated livers, a few at a time, into hot oil; cover with a splatter screen and cook until crisp and golden brown, 5 to 6 minutes.

review.reviewBody: Easy to follow, delicious
I added a little cayenne pepper to the flour mixture. tasted just perfect for me.
Real good, yum.
I doubled dipped livers to get proper coating.
Home cooking family favorite.
Turned out wonderful and tasted great üëç
Followed the recipe, super easy!! I did end up seasoning them with a little more salt and some Tony Chacheres. OMG.. absolutely delicious!!

I decided to try this recipe last night, and it was a huge hit. I had never cooked chicken livers before, but this recipe was so simple and easy to follow. My family was eating them like candy. I'll definitely be making them again.

I liked the recipe a lot. I changed it to first dredge in flour, then in egg mixture & then dredge in the flour again. Then drop into the heated oil to fry. The coating stays on the liver better. I was gonna try buttermilk but the milk turned out ok.
I loved this recipe. I ran out of flour so I used corn meal and bread crumbs half way through. I also added red pepper to the flour and a lot of it.

Basically the same recipe I have cooked for 50 years except for garlic powder. To eliminate the splattering, poke the livers several times with a fork before frying. I usually do this before battering.
I cook them outside on my gas grill for less mess. Also do that when cooking bacon.
I'm no t much for liver but every one loved it thank you for the great easy recipe ü§óüôè
That's goremay gas station food! For real these were really üëç
Added more garlic powder and paprika. Very good! Easy to prepare

I just made these and they were fantastic! I don‚Äôt have a picture because I ate them too fast! I used a plugged skillet with lid that allowed me to set the right temperature. I followed instructions for a sample batch and decided it needed a little more. The 2nd batch I added Tony Chachere‚Äôs creole seasoning to the flour and a sprinkle over top right out of the fryer. They were fantastic after! Thanks Mythical Chef Josh! Tony C‚Äôs does go on everything!

This was really good. I took the advice of others and pierced the livers. They did not splatter grease at all. They cooked up nice and crispy. I guessed at the amount of spices. Next time I will add more spices to the flour mixture. There will be a next time as the only other way to get fried livers is to drive 20 miles to the only restaurant that serves them.
Great recipe
There‚Äôs no words for how delicious

I chopped up the liver into tiny pieces, dropped them all into the egg and milk mixture, then strained the pieces out to throw in the bag with the flour mix, then dumped it all into the skillet. I also threw in a chicken heart. Delicious!
This is not traditional southern chicken livers. All you need is a brown paper bag, livers, salt, pepper and pan to get in.
So crunchy and full of flavor.
Very good recipe. It past the hubby tummy test. Said I can make them any time I like he will be glad to eat them all! Thanks!
God these are good. I need to learn how to bake them so the breading doesn't come off.

This is a simple recipe that always works. I heavily season my flour mixture with granulated garlic, onion powder, salt, good pepper, dried parsley flakes. I do not heat the oil to 375 because that temp is too hot. I heat to between 360-365 and cook them for about half the time the recipe says. Livers are very tender and cook quickly. The high temps and long frying time renders the livers hard, dry, and quite overcooked.

I'm glad all those people before had a decent 
review....but if you follow we the directions to a "T" it makes no sense at all! If you don't cook then this will eff up your meal
Great...Reminds me of my grandmother‚Äôs recipe...

Love the chicken livers, I ended up adding garlic salt to my own portion as to not over salt the whole batch. five to six minutes was perfect. Not sure what to do with the leftover oil, will search for suggestions.
Just like I remembered.
Husband loved them, but we didn‚Äôt care for the garlic powder. Will use poultry seasoning with s&p next time.
It was easy and delicious. I also pan fried but finished in a low oven.

This was very good but I like to fry onions first and add the chicken livers to them with more butter and fry in the pan on medium. Add some fresh squeezed lemon over top for a nice lemon buttery taste.
This is a very good recipe, but using a deep fat fryer, I suggest checking to see if they are cooked at the 4 minute mark, maybe even a tad sooner.
I‚Äôve made these twice now. My husband and I love them! Definitely a keeper!
Delicious! The recipe is not lying about the popping oil, I had to google "what to put on oil burns" right after making this recipe XD Its worth the pain tho..
Great, easy and quick. I added Soul Food Seasoning and original Mrs. Dash. I mixed corn meal with the flour for a definitive crunch.

If you poke the chicken livers with toothpicks or with forks it will not pop you the way it does if you don't poke them trust me on this you want to poke the krapp out of the chicken liver before you put it in to the oil.

I made it exactly as written and it was every bit as good as I remember my mom making. I will not do it again without the protective screen. Although I didn't get burned I had to scrub down my kitchen. Believe the warning about the livers popping.
I used half cup of canola oil in iron skillet and went with the recipe. Love em
These were awesome!
Just followed the recipe. I‚Äôll make it again.

I have a hard time looking at the reviews. Some people need to post ** their ** recipe. This was lip smacking just as is. Alot said flour batter flour. Not for me. I wanna taste the liver NOT batter - Thanks for an awaesome recipe !!

Very good. I cooked up 1.5 pounds with the same recipe and they were gone quickly; no time for a picture for you. I warmed the oil in my dutch oven so the hot splatters wouldn't burn me. They were crispy and yummy.
Good chicken livers. Made just like the recipe. Dipped them in ranch dressing. Delicious.
I marinated the chicken livers in buttermilk mixed with a little hot sauce before dredging in the flour mixture and frying.
Not one liver popped! Using a fork to puncture the livers before cooking worked great! Great taste too. I will be making these more often now. Thank you!
Added Montreal Steal Seasoning and one of my friends said they were the best finger steaks he had ever tasted! LOL!
My mother did these when I was growing up. We used Heinz 57 to dip them in.....try it, wonderful.
Husband wants me to make them again!
I do think I need to either add more salt and pepper or some season salt. But I still love em!
The kids loved it as well. I added chilli pepper powder to my flour mixture.

Simple and Delicious! I also used the leftover egg mixture and flour to make a simple pepper gravy by adding about 3/4 cup of milk and a couple of tablespoons of the flour along with more pepper to the egg wash and nuked it for two minutes for a nice no waste pepper gravy.
Easy, exonomical and yummy!
This recipe makes perfect breaded, fried liver. The seasonings are the perfect compliment and the liver is melt in your mouth.
I used 1/2 cup of cornstarch (or potato starch) with 1/2 cup of flour and they came out extra crispy!
Delicious!
I made these, they were awesome....nothing but crumbs left....and request for me to make them again.....
It's a good recipe but it is chicken livers. I cook them different all the time. I like to sometimes cook them much longer, I like to add onion rings using the same batter.
Yes after frying the liver I smothered them in onions and gravy. Yes I will make again.
My husband and I love chicken livers. This is a simple, easy and tasty recipe!
I would. make these again.

a bit mealy....maybe it was the livers...they were from an organic farm near here....great finger food while watching a footw
ball game
Excellent recipe! My husband loved them! I served them with dirty rice (my own recipe: if it looks good g, throw it in). I'll keep making it this way.

and yet again- 5 stars!!! as I only do fried foods a couple of times a year- I double the recipe- no salt- add a tablespoon each- fresh cracked black pepper and chipotle powder- I had 2 pounds livers and a pound of gizzards for hubs- served with fried taters and onions- and English peas- yum-- made enough for a couple of lunches- was wonderful as always- thanks again for the perfect recipe Cindy- yes- fork the livers- it really works- had only one pop from the 2 pounds:-) photos- now, if I can figure out how to post them-lol
The milk and egg helped the flour to stick but, this recipe needs more spice.

I was looking for a basic recipe and this was it. I fried them in lard like my grandmother did. I ended up changing deep fry to pan fry and added cayenne pepper to the flour. Dipped in store bought Tabasco ketchup. Will make again.
I made these as the recipe suggests with the exception of using a deep fryer. These are wonderful as is.
Most definitely a keeper, it will be used again in the near future!!

OH YEAH! made this for lunch today, and it took me back when I lived in Bloomingdale, GA.. Oh the yumminess! Very very good, the only thing I did different is sprinkle Louisiana Hot Sauce on top when they where done... Oh So Good! Will definitely make this recipe again.. Thank you :)
I loved it and yes I will def. make it again
My husband loved the chicken livers. He said they were tender and the liked the seasoning. I'm glad I read the previous reviews at the splattering because I came prepared.

Hubby and I love chicken livers. First time making this way. Did not care for the egg/milk combo and will leave it out next time. . I usually just flour and deep fry in a deep skillet . I gave it a 5 star because we definitely liked the added garlic powder. Also liked the idea of poking each piece to avoid the popping. It worked!
I used oil and 1 stick of butter to fry in. These are delicious and have copied the recipes I didn't give it a 5 taking off one star for not mentioning prepping chicken livers before cooking

These came out very delicious. As the previous reviewers have mentioned, it is important to poke the livers to prevent popping. I like to cut them up into smaller bits because they taste better to me. Also, I added Nature's Seasoning to my egg/milk mixture as well as my garlic powder/ flour mixture. I just sprinkled about a half to a whole teaspoon altogether of the Nature's Seasoning to add an extra "umph" to the recipe. (I love using Nature's Seasoning to almost everything I cook because it has a perfect blend of salt, pepper, garlic powder, onion powder, and parsley flakes)........I also pan-fried these babies in a cast iron skillet. Wow! I will definitely make these again! Thanks everyone for the pointers!

For those of you that love fried chicken livers you might want to try this also...after you fry the chicken livers let them cool then marinate in Italian salad dressing for a few hours or longer then serve on a bed of lettuce of your choice. I used to go to a restaurant in Atlanta that served chicken livers this way as an appetizer.
I believe I used too much oil. Otherwise it was good

Excellent recipe. Like some other reviewers I repeated the breading process. I also poked the livers with a fork. 

I typically fry in a 1/2 inch of oil rather than deep fry, which I did in this case, using coconut oil. 

I mixed a some siracha and mayo for a dip. 

Best liver ever. I found it hard to save some for my husband.

I did make changes. I was looking for a recipe that was like what I used to eat at a restuarant in mid missouri. This was close, I combined this one with the recipe for garlic chicken liver. I added lemon, garlic and olive oil directly to to the very very well drained chicken livers. ( I think that is the biggest key to making liver is to make sure they are well rinsed and drained) Then, I dunk and dip them and put them in the oil. I put enough oil in the deep pan to be like a deep fryer. But, when they stop really sizzling I was able to stir them. 
When removing from oil use plenty of paper towels to pat dry.

First time ever making chicken livers and they turned out awesome! Only change I made was about half the garlic and I shallow pan fried them. I don't really like chicken livers that much but my 85-year old mother loves them so I thought I would give it a try. I used the "poking with a fork" trick, which works like a charm, to keep them from popping so much. Believe me when they tell you these will splatter you had better believe them. My microwave is covered with cooking oil after the first two that I did not poke full of holes. I have a couple burns for my trouble as well. Be careful!! Hoping there are some of these left to take to Mom. They are pretty tasty! Thank you so much for the recipe and all the hints and tips. Especially the one about poking them with the fork.
Very tasty. I used 1/2 corn meal and half flour.

These are Excellent made this one , one time. I skip everything else just the flour and egg.

Salt and Pepper the flour and dip the livers in the flour egg and flour again. I do not deep fry them I shallow fry them. Heat up Avocado Oil I use that oil due to its very high heat tolerance. Get the Oil very hot and gently place them in the pan and cook 2-3 minutes on each side remove from the skillet place them on a wire rack to cook and touch it off with some salt while hot they get nice and crispy and make a chili sour cream dipping sauce.
Fantastic

I just made these chicken livers. Yum! I followed the advice of others who said, flour, dredge, then flour again. Kinda messy but effective for light but crispy crust. I also soaked my chicken livers in white distilled vinegar before cooking to get rid of any bitter taste. Tender chewy livers with a crispy crust...Winner Winner Chicken liver dinner! Thank you!

I am a, born n raised in Alabama, southern girl.. Chicken livers have been a favorite of mine since childhood and I have had them many ways.. This recipe is simple and delicious! I only have two small tips for first timers.. Using a fork, untrue each liver a few times and it will reduce/stop all the popping while frying. And serve with your favorite hot sauce!!! Much better tan gravy....just sayin' ;-)
great!!!

I love chicken livers, but was getting bored of frying them with onions. I figured I'd try this recipe, and I couldn't be happier with the results.

I tried them with various hot sauces and honey mustard, all were good, but I think I could do better for the sauce. Time to experiment.
outstanding! !

They came out much better than when i usually make them. The egg wash made a big difference. Might change my seasonings a little bit too give it more kick next time. Thanks for the tip on how to keep the oil from popping.
Wonderful!
Loved these chicken livers. Likely the best I have ever had. Can be pan fried if you prefer.
Trying it today! Love chicken livers and I remember my mom cooking them for our family. Brings back good memories! Thanks for the reminder.
Hubby loved it.
Very good. I fried them in peanut oil in my electric skillet. Had very little popping during frying.

Soaked trimmed livers for a few hours in fridge in buttermilk and hot sauce to which I added a beaten egg. Added livers to bag of flour with the garlic powder, onion powder, salt and lots of black pepper. Sealed bag and kept turning it to move livers around. Left livers in the flour until ready to cook. Pan-fried in about a half inch of hot oil, punctured them and had no spattering at all. Absolutely delicious. Served with some leftover gravy and potatoes. Not one left!
This is a perfect fried chicken livers recipe. They were very quick and simple to make and they were delicious. I will definitely be making these on a regular basis.
This is absolutely delicious with the Spicy Fry Sauce recipe here on allrecipe.com. Yummy!

I used my electric fry pan that has a lid and fried at 375 degrees. The garlic really makes a difference and I always put hot sauce (Franks) in my milk dredge. Served over rice with peppermill gravy. .

Wow, I have always loved chicken livers. This recipe is exactly the same I have used, except this one adds garlic powder. It made an amazing improvement on what I have loved for years. Thanks so much!

Great recipe ! I devised a solution to your spatter problem ! The water inside the livers are what causes it to spatter when it hits the hot oil. After rinsing the livers in the colander I placed several layers of paper-towel in a large bowl and put the livers on top, then placed several layers on top and covered with seran wrap and let it sit in the fridge for an hour. Once they come out they will be relatively dry (accepting the dredge more easily) and won't spatter at all. Hope this tip helps !
